title: Against Anton-Wilsonism
summary:
Key ideas
- The author talks about his experiences with mysticism and occultism during his college days.
- He uses his interest in physics in high school as an analogy to compare his interest in mysticism.
- The author highlights how learning about mysticism is different from learning mysticism.
- He explains how authors like Robert Anton Wilson can promote dabbling and provide a false sense of reward.
- The author emphasizes the importance of not getting carried away with acquiring knowledge about mysticism and instead focusing on practicing it.

Key learnings
- Learning about a field is different from learning the field.
- Reading extensively about mysticism can give a false sense of accomplishment.
- Searching for the perfect combination of spiritual beliefs can lead to always changing and never practicing.
- To be good at mysticism, one needs to have a solid consistent base.

Key questions
- How does dabbling in mysticism compare to dabbling in other forms of knowledge?
- Can one truly understand mysticism without practice?
- What are the dangers of getting too caught up in acquiring knowledge about mysticism?
